sen.j: 相馬 主計（そうま かずえ、天保6年（1835年）或いは14年（1843年） - 明治8年（1875年）？）は、新選組最後の隊長。
sen.e: Kazue SOMA (1835 or 1843 - 1875?) was the last commander of the Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate).
sen.cmt: 新選組→the Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate)としました。
sen.e: Kazue SOMA (1835 or 1843 - 1875?) was the last commander of the Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate).
Kazue SOMA (1835 or 1843 - 1875?) was the last commander of the Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate).

sen.j: 名は肇、明治以降は主殿。
sen.e: His personal name was Hajime, and from the Meiji Period he served as one of tonomori (an occupational group in charge of the care and maintenance of all the palace buildings).
His personal name was Hajime, and from the Meiji Period he served as one of tonomori (an occupational group in charge of the care and maintenance of all the palace buildings).
His personal name was Hajime, and from the Meiji Period he served as one of tonomori (an occupational group in charge of the care and maintenance of all the palace buildings).

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

tit.e: Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate)
Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate)
Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate)

sen.j: 常陸笠間藩藩士・船橋平八郎義方の息子として生まれた。
sen.e: Heihachiro-Yoshikata FUNABASHI, a retainer of the Kasama Domain in Hitachi Province
He was born as a son of Heihachiro-Yoshikata FUNABASHI, a retainer of the Kasama Domain in Hitachi Province.
sen.cmt: 「の息子として生まれた」の部分が訳もれ。ピリオドを追加しました。
sen.e: He was born as a son of Heihachiro-Yoshikata FUNABASHI, a retainer of the Kasama Domain in Hitachi Province.

sen.j: その後、慶応元年(1865)脱藩し、幕府歩兵の徴募に応じ第二次長州征伐の際は三津浦(現愛媛県松山市)に駐屯した。
sen.e: After he left the domain in 1865, he applied for the recruitment of Shogunate Infantry, and was stationed in Mitsuura (present Matsuyama City, Aichi Prefecture) during the Second Conquest of Choshu.
After he left the domain in 1865, he applied for the recruitment of Shogunate Infantry, and was stationed in Mitsuura (present Matsuyama City, Aichi Prefecture) during the Second Conquest of Choshu.
After he left the domain in 1865, he applied for the recruitment of Shogunate Infantry, and was stationed in Mitsuura (present Matsuyama City, Aichi Prefecture) during the Second Conquest of Choshu.

sen.j: その後解兵となり、新選組に加入した。
sen.e: Afterwards, he was discharged from the infantry, and joined the Shinsengumi.
Afterwards, he was discharged from the infantry, and joined the Shinsengumi.
Afterwards, he was discharged from the infantry, and joined the Shinsengumi.

sen.j: ただ相馬がいつ新選組に入隊したかの詳細は不明である（慶応3年10月説あり）。
sen.e: However, the date of the enrolment in the Shinsengumi is not clear (according to one theory, it was on October 1867[表記の変更])
However, the date of the enrolment in the Shinsengumi is not clear (according to one theory, it was in October 1867).
sen.cmt: on October ⇒ in October, [表記の変更]を削除しました。ピリオドを追加しました。
sen.e: However, the date of the enrolment in the Shinsengumi is not clear (according to one theory, it was in October 1867).

sen.j: 慶応4年1月の鳥羽・伏見の戦いの時には入隊している。
sen.e: By the Battle of Toba-Fushimi that broke out in January 1868 (表記の変更), he had already joined the force.
By the Battle of Toba-Fushimi that broke out in January 1868, he had already joined the force.
sen.cmt: (表記の変更)を削除しました。
sen.e: By the Battle of Toba-Fushimi that broke out in January 1868, he had already joined the force.

sen.j: おそらく天満屋事件の時には仮隊士として入隊していたと思われる。
sen.e: Probably, he must have been a probationary member when the Tenmanya Incident occurred.
Probably, he must have been a probationary member when the Tenmanya Incident occurred.
Probably, he must have been a probationary member when the Tenmanya Incident occurred.

sen.j: その後、甲陽鎮撫隊では局長付組頭として頭角を現し、流山で近藤勇が新政府軍に投降し、板橋の総督府に出頭すると、幕府陸軍軍事方、松濤権之丞の書状を携え、近藤の助命のために板橋を訪れた。
sen.e: Later, in the Koyo Chinbutai (a military unit formed specially for the campaign in Kai Province) he distinguished himself as the chief of the direct attendant group on Commander, and when Isami KONDO surrendered to the New government army in Nagareyama and presented himself at the government-general in Itabashi, Soma visited Itabashi to beg for Kondo's life with the letter of Shogunate Army Gunjikata (officer in charge of military affaires), Gennojo MATSUNAMI.
sen.cmt: 局長付組頭→定訳不明：chief of the direct attendant group to Commanderとしました。 軍事方→定訳不明：Gunjikata (officer in charge of military affaires)としました。
sen.e: Later, in the Koyo Chinbutai (a military unit formed specially for the campaign in Kai Province) he distinguished himself as the chief of the direct attendant group on Commander, and when Isami KONDO surrendered to the New government army in Nagareyama and presented himself at the government-general in Itabashi, Soma visited Itabashi to beg for Kondo's life with the letter of Shogunate Army Gunjikata (officer in charge of military affaires), Gennojo MATSUNAMI.

Later, in the Koyo Chinbutai (a military unit formed specially for the campaign in Kai Province) he distinguished himself as the chief of the direct attendant group on Commander, and when Isami KONDO surrendered to the New government army in Nagareyama and presented himself at the government-general in Itabashi, Soma visited Itabashi to beg for Kondo's life with the letter of Shogunate Army Gunjikata (officer in charge of military affaires), Gennojo MATSUNAMI.

sen.j: しかし、近藤はすでに捕縛されていたことから、相馬もまた仲間として捕縛されてしまう。
sen.e: However, as Kondo had been already captured, Soma was also detained there at once.
However, as Kondo had been already captured, Soma was also detained there as a Kondo's ally.
However, as Kondo had been already captured, Soma was also detained there as a Kondo's ally.

sen.j: 4月25日、近藤勇と一緒に処刑されるはずだったが、近藤の助命により、一緒に捕縛されていた野村利三郎と共に処刑を免れ、笠間藩に預けられ謹慎する。
sen.e: Soma was scheduled to be executed on May 17, 1868 (表記の変更) together with Kondo, thanks to Kondo, who begged for Kazue's life, he and Risaburo NOMURA, who was also captured, were spared from the execution, and they were ordered to put a rein on their own behavior under the custody of the Kasama Domain.

Though Soma was scheduled to be executed on May 17, 1868 together with Kondo, thanks to Kondo, who begged for Kazue's life, he and Risaburo NOMURA, who was also captured, were spared from the execution, and they were ordered to put a rein on their own behavior under the custody of the Kasama Domain.
sen.cmt: (表記の変更)を削除しました。文頭にThough を追加しました。
sen.e: Though Soma was scheduled to be executed on May 17, 1868 together with Kondo, thanks to Kondo, who begged for Kazue's life, he and Risaburo NOMURA, who was also captured, were spared from the execution, and they were ordered to put a rein on their own behavior under the custody of the Kasama Domain.

sen.j: この後、脱走し、彰義隊に加入。
sen.e: After a while, he escaped from the domain, and joined the Shogitai (group of former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government who fought in the Battle of Ueno).
After a while, he escaped from the domain, and joined the Shogitai (group of former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government who fought in the Battle of Ueno).
After a while, he escaped from the domain, and joined the Shogitai (group of former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government who fought in the Battle of Ueno).

sen.j: のちに陸軍隊春日左衛門の支配下に入り、彰義隊瓦解後、旧幕臣らとともに磐城方面を転戦する。
sen.e: He later entered into the Shogunate Army to work under the direction of Saemon KASUGA, and after the Shogitai (group of former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government who fought in the Battle of Ueno) was fallen apart to pieces, he fought in one place after another toward the Iwaki Province with other former Tokugawa retainers.
sen.cmt: 陸軍隊→Shogunate Army としました。
sen.e: He later entered into the Shogunate Army to work under the direction of Saemon KASUGA, and after the Shogitai (group of former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government who fought in the Battle of Ueno) was fallen apart to pieces, he fought in one place after another toward the Iwaki Province with other former Tokugawa retainers.

He later entered into the Shogunate Army to work under the direction of Saemon KASUGA, and after the Shogitai (group of former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government who fought in the Battle of Ueno) was fallen apart to pieces, he fought in one place after another toward the Iwaki Province with other former Tokugawa retainers.

sen.j: その後、仙台で土方と再会。
sen.e: Later, he met Hijikata again in Sendai.
Later, he met Hijikata again in Sendai.
Later, he met Hijikata again in Sendai.

sen.j: 戊辰戦争の最終地である箱館五稜郭へと転戦し、主に箱館市中の取締の任にあたる。
sen.e: After having fought in various battles, he reached Hakodate Goryokaku, which later became the final field of the Boshin War, and he took charge of controlling the Hakodate City.
After having fought in various battles, he reached Hakodate Goryokaku, which was the final field of the Boshin War, and he took charge of controlling Hakodate City mainly.
sen.cmt: later became ⇒ was, 「主に」訳抜け, the Hakodate City の the を削除しました。
sen.e: After having fought in various battles, he reached Hakodate Goryokaku, which was the final field of the Boshin War, and he took charge of controlling Hakodate City mainly.

sen.j: 明治2年5月11日、新選組を統率していた土方歳三が戦死すると、弁天台場の新選組は相馬を隊長として恭順の書状に名前をしたため、新選組の歴史に幕を引いた。
sen.e: After Toshizo HIJIKARA, who was leading the Shinsengumi, died in battle on June 20, 1869 (表記の変更), the Shinsengumi members staying in Benten Daiba (Cape Benten Battery) presented a letter of obedience to the new government with the name of Soma at the head of the letter as Commander, which finally closed the curtain on the history of Shinsengumi.
sen.cmt: 恭順の書状letter of obedienceとしました。
sen.e: After Toshizo HIJIKARA, who was leading the Shinsengumi, died in battle on June 20, 1869, the Shinsengumi members staying in Benten Daiba (Cape Benten Battery) presented a letter of obedience to the new government with the name of Soma at the head of the letter as Commander, which finally closed the curtain on the history of the Shinsengumi.
sen.cmt: (表記の変更)を削除しました。Shinsengumi に the を追加しました。
sen.e: After Toshizo HIJIKARA, who was leading the Shinsengumi, died in battle on June 20, 1869, the Shinsengumi members staying in Benten Daiba (Cape Benten Battery) presented a letter of obedience to the new government with the name of Soma at the head of the letter as Commander, which finally closed the curtain on the history of the Shinsengumi.

sen.j: 正式な就任日は高松凌雲の書簡によると5月15日という。
sen.e: According to Ryoun TAKAMATSU's letter, Soma's assumption of the commander was on June 24, 1869 (表記の変更).
According to Ryoun TAKAMATSU's letter, Soma's assumption of the commander was on June 24, 1869.
sen.cmt: (表記の変更)を削除しました。
sen.e: According to Ryoun TAKAMATSU's letter, Soma's assumption of the commander was on June 24, 1869.

sen.j: 明治3年10月10日、伊東甲子太郎暗殺の嫌疑により、終身流罪となり、伊豆新島に流される。
sen.e: On November 3, 1870 (表記の変更) Soma, alleged that he assassinated Kashitaro ITO, was condemned to transportation and deported to Nii-jima Island of Izu.
On November 3, 1870, Soma was alleged to have assassinated Kashitaro ITO and was condemned to transportation, and deported to Nii-jima Island of Izu.
sen.cmt: (表記の変更)を削除しました。Octoberのうしろにカンマを追加しました。alleged をwas alleged の形にし、and で次のフレーズと結合させました。
sen.e: On November 3, 1870, Soma was alleged to have assassinated Kashitaro ITO and was condemned to transportation, and deported to Nii-jima Island of Izu.

sen.j: 大工棟梁・植村甚兵衛に身柄を預けられ、その場所で寺子屋を開く。
sen.e: In the island he opened a terakoya (small private school) under the custody of a master carpenter, Jinbei UEMURA.
In the island he opened a terakoya (small private school) under the custody of a master carpenter, Jinbei UEMURA.
In the island he opened a terakoya (small private school) under the custody of a master carpenter, Jinbei UEMURA.

sen.j: のちに甚兵衛の長女マツと結婚した。
sen.e: Later he got married with the first daughter of Jinbei, Matsu.
Later he got married with the first daughter of Jinbei, Matsu.
Later he got married with the first daughter of Jinbei, Matsu.

sen.j: 明治5年、赦免され、東京の「くらまえ」と称する場所に妻マツと暮らした。
sen.e: In 1872 (表記の変更), he was pardoned and lived in a place called 'Kuramae' in Tokyo with his wife Matsu.
In 1872, he was pardoned and lived in a place called 'Kuramae' in Tokyo with his wife Matsu.
sen.cmt: (表記の変更)を削除しました。
sen.e: In 1872, he was pardoned and lived in a place called 'Kuramae' in Tokyo with his wife Matsu.

sen.j: 翌年、豊岡県権参事だった大野右仲の推薦からか、同県へ15等出仕として勤務する。
sen.e: The next year, he began working for the Toyooka Prefecture (former Toyooka Domain) as 15th rank attendant, probably on the coattails of the recommendation of Uchu ONO's recommendation, who was Gonsanji (second to the governor) of Toyooka Prefecture (former Toyooka Domain) at that time.
sen.cmt: 同県→Toyooka Prefecture (former Toyooka Domain) としました。 15等出仕→定訳不明：15th rank attendantとしました。 豊岡県権参事→定訳不明Gonsanji (second to the governor) of Toyooka Prefecture (former Toyooka Domain)としました。
sen.e: Next year, he began working for the Toyooka Prefecture (former Toyooka Domain) as the 15th rank attendant, probably with the backing of Uchu ONO, who was Gonsanji (second to the governor) of Toyooka Prefecture (former Toyooka Domain) at that time.
sen.cmt: next year の the を削除しました。15th の前に the を追加しました。probably on the coattails of the recommendation of Uchu ONO's recommendation ⇒ probably with the backing of Uchu ONO に訂正しました。
sen.e: Next year, he began working for the Toyooka Prefecture (former Toyooka Domain) as the 15th rank attendant, probably with the backing of Uchu ONO, who was Gonsanji (second to the governor) of Toyooka Prefecture (former Toyooka Domain) at that time.

sen.j: 翌年には14等出仕に昇進し、主に司法方面の勤務に就いた。
sen.e: In 1874 (表記の変更), he was promoted to 14等出仕14th rank attendant and worked in the judicial branch.
sen.cmt: 14等出仕→定訳不明：14th rank attendantとしました。 司法方面→judicial branchとしました。
sen.e: In 1874, he was promoted to the 14th rank attendant and worked in the judicial branch.
sen.cmt: (表記の変更)を削除しました。「14等出仕」を削除し、theを追加しました。
sen.e: In 1874, he was promoted to the 14th rank attendant and worked in the judicial branch.

sen.j: 死
sen.e: Death
Death
Death

sen.j: 明治8年2月、豊岡県内部の抗争のためか、突如免官され、東京に戻る。
sen.e: On February 1875 (表記の変更), he was suddenly dismissed from his post probably because of an internal conflict in Toyooka Prefecture, and returned to Tokyo.
In February 1875, he was suddenly dismissed from his post probably because of an internal conflict in Toyooka Prefecture, and returned to Tokyo.
sen.cmt: (表記の変更)を削除しました。On February ⇒ In に訂正しました。
sen.e: In February 1875, he was suddenly dismissed from his post probably because of an internal conflict in Toyooka Prefecture, and returned to Tokyo.

sen.j: その後、通説では、自殺したと伝わっている。
sen.e: Afterwards, in popular lore he committed suicide.
Afterwards, in popular lore he committed suicide.
Afterwards, in popular lore he committed suicide.

sen.j: それによればマツが外出先から帰ってきた際、すでに相馬は障子を真っ赤に染め、介錯もなく割腹を遂げていたという。
sen.e: According to that, when Matsu returned home, the paper screens were stained in bloody red and Soma had already committed disembowelment without taking any assistant.
According to that, when Matsu returned home, the paper screens were stained in bloody red and Soma had already committed disembowelment without being assisted.
sen.cmt: without taking any assistant ⇒ without being assisted
sen.e: According to that, when Matsu returned home, the paper screens were stained in bloody red and Soma had already committed disembowelment without being assisted.

sen.j: その際、相馬自身がマツに「他言無用」と厳命し、マツが生涯その命を守り通したため、自殺の詳細や動機、また菩提寺については現在に至るまで不明である。
sen.e: With his last breath, Soma himself strictly ordered Matsu 'not to breath a word of it,' and since Matsu kept his order until she died, the details and motive as well as the temple where he was buried are unknown to date.
sen.cmt: 「他言無用」→'not to breath a word of it' としました。
sen.e: With his last breath, Soma himself strictly ordered Matsu 'not to breath a word of it,' and since Matsu kept his order until she died, the details and motive as well as the temple where he was buried are unknown to date.

With his last breath, Soma himself strictly ordered Matsu 'not to breath a word of it,' and since Matsu kept his order until she died, the details and motive as well as the temple where he was buried are unknown to date.
